results.headline: Review: In ‘Body,’ a Mansion Turns Into a House of Horror
results.summary_short: A holiday romp for three women goes wrong in this new film from Dan Berk and Robert Olsen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Body

results.headline: Review: ‘Don Verdean,’ a Sendup of Ambitious Pastors and the Lure of Religious Relics
results.summary_short: Jared and Jerusha Hess’s film stars Sam Rockwell as an archaeologist who finds himself in a quandary after a pastor asks him to track down Holy Land artifacts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Don Verdean

results.headline: Review: ‘American Hero,’ a Deadbeat Superhero, Forever Backsliding
results.summary_short: Stephen Dorff stars as Melvin, an absentee dad who has the power to move objects with his mind, in this movie written and directed by Nick Love.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Hero

results.headline: Review: ‘Stinking Heaven,’ a Portrait of Addicts in Turmoil
results.summary_short: Nathan Silver’s latest film unfolds in the early 1990s in suburban New Jersey, where a house has become a treatment center.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stinking Heaven

results.headline: Review: ‘The Messenger’ Documents Avian Struggles
results.summary_short: This film by Su Rynard tracks the global environmental difficulties facing birds, suggesting that they presage trouble for the human race as well.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Messenger

results.headline: Review: Spike Lee’s ‘Chi-Raq,’ a Barbed Takedown of Gang Wars, With Sex as the Weapon
results.summary_short: Set in contemporary Chicago, this film is inspired by Aristophanes’ “Lysistrata,” in which women organize a sex strike to force men to end the bloodshed.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chi-raq

results.display_title: Orion: The Man Who Would Be King
results.headline: Review: ‘Orion’ Tells an Elvis Tale
results.summary_short: Jeanie Finlay’s documentary tracks the Presley sound-alike singer Jimmy Ellis, whose career took off after Presley’s death.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Orion: The Man Who Would Be King

results.headline: Review: ‘Dementia,’ Where Misery Is Company
results.summary_short: The titular illness is not the only disorder in the family of a Vietnam veteran who is recovering from a stroke.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dementia

results.headline: Review: ‘Bikes vs Cars’ Explores the Debate in Cyclist-Friendly Cities
results.summary_short: From a cabdriver in Copenhagen to an activist in São Paulo, Fredrik Gertten’s documentary presents a wide range of viewpoints.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bikes vs Cars

results.headline: Review: ‘The Letters,’ a Biopic of Mother Teresa
results.summary_short: William Riead’s film follows this nun as she decides to work with the impoverished in Kolkata.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Letters

results.headline: Review: Sorrentino’s ‘Youth’: A Euro Buddy Film
results.summary_short: Michael Caine and Harvey Keitel, playing a composer and a filmmaker, look back on their long friendship from the perspective of an exclusive Alpine retreat.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Youth

results.headline: Review: ‘Macbeth,’ Starring Michael Fassbender, Awash in Gorgeous Carnage
results.summary_short: Justin Kurzel’s film suggests that there is a timeless quality to slaughter, raising questions about Macbeth’s guilt and freedom of will.

results.headline: Review: In Wim Wenders’s ‘Every Thing Will Be Fine,’ Nothing Is
results.summary_short: James Franco stars in this film about a emotionally detached writer who runs over a small child.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everything Will Be Fine

results.headline: Review: In ‘The World of Kanako,’ the Old Ultraviolence
results.summary_short: Tetsuya Nakashima’s film about a father trying to rescue his teenage daughter from the Japanese underworld glories in its lurid bloodthirstiness.

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Wannabe,’ Drugs, Money and Aspirations to Join the Gotti Circle
results.summary_short: This modest, assured and cautionary gangland character study starring Vincent Piazza and Patricia Arquette isn’t short on mob cred.

results.headline: Review: In ‘River of Fundament,’ Matthew Barney Contemplates Waste
results.summary_short: This work by Mr. Barney includes macabre scenes of filth and sex.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Night Owls,’ Staying Up Late Leads to Surprises
results.summary_short: Rosa Salazar and Adam Pally race though a spectrum of emotions before sunrise in “Night Owls.”

results.headline: Review: In ‘Krampus,’ the Holiday Involves a Demonic Santa
results.summary_short: A family, stressed over the holidays, unleashes the wrath of Santa’s “shadow,” a demon won comes “to punish.”

results.headline: Review: Chronicling an Outsider in ‘Almost There’
results.summary_short: This documentary from Dan Rybicky and Aaron Wickenden follows the story of Peter Anton, an artist in Indiana.

results.headline: Review: ‘Arabian Nights’ Offers Satirical Fabulism Amid Economic Austerity
results.summary_short: Miguel Gomes’s trilogy uses a famous work of literature as a conceit, a plaything and a structural principle.
